subject: Re: [junit] overriding a method executed in the constructor: dont't work.
msgSnippet: Just a nit, but... ... That method is overridden, not overloaded, which means something different. As for the problem at hand, Java handles it better then C++
messageBody:
Just a nit, but...

On 12/11/05, Jeff Nielsen <jeff.nielsen@...> wrote:
>
> By calling an (overloaded) class method from within the constructor


That method is overridden, not overloaded, which means something different.

As for the problem at hand, Java handles it better then C++ but I agree with
Jeff, you should avoid calling public or protected methods from your
constructor.

--
Cédric
http://testng.org


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
